column108:
In September 2015, rabid wild fox entered the pastoralist
village and bit a domestic dog. The victim dog had turned rabid
after four months and bit livestock, and rabies outbreak occurred
in the family livestock. Consequently, one bull, one lactating cow,
one calf, two donkeys and one heifer died of outbreak; After five months, one
heifer and a donkey from a neighbor became rabid
and died after a week of clinical signs.
column109:
in cattle: excessive salivation, behavioral
change, yawning, abnormal bellowing, pica in one
case (biting wooden material), a lactating cow
refused calf to suckle. In donkey: aggressiveness,
kicking, attempt to bite other animals, biting its
own body (one case) to the level of inflicting
itself.

The virus is widespread in Brazil with a seroprevalence higher than
50% in several regions in domestic species. The co-circulation of various BTV strains within the same animal population enhances the possibility of viral reassortment and occurrence of novel serotypes with unknown phenotypic and pathogenic characteristics.

described or isolated in Brazil, either in wild or domestic ruminants
